title: Rates of Change - rates of rates of change

content.question: <math alttext="negative 2"><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math><math alttext="negative 1"><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math><math alttext="0"><mn>0</mn></math><math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math><math alttext="f open parentheses x close parentheses"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math><math alttext="5"><semantics><mn>5</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math><math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math><math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math><math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> ​The table gives values of a function <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> for selected values of <math alttext="x"><mi>x</mi></math>. Which of the following conclusions with reason is consistent with the data in the table?

choices.label: <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a linear function because the rates of change over consecutive equal-length intervals in the table can be described by <math alttext="y equals 2 x"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>.

​<math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a linear function because the rates of change over consecutive equal-length intervals in the table can be described by <math alttext="y equals 2 x plus 1"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.

​<math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a quadratic function because the rates of change over consecutive equal-length intervals in the table can be described by <math alttext="y equals 2 x"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></math>.

​<math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a quadratic function because the rates of change over consecutive equal-length intervals in the table can be described by <math alttext="y equals 2 x plus 1"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.

content.answer: ​<math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a quadratic function because the rates of change over consecutive equal-length intervals in the table can be described by <math alttext="y equals 2 x plus 1"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>.

topic.text: 1.3: Rates of Change in Linear and Quadratic Functions

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Support conclusions or choices with a logical rationale or appropriate data.
